(3) What is API Documentation?

  • Noun
    • a human-readable description of how developers will enable machines to communicate with each other


What is API Documentation? Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(4) Who is API Documentation For?

  • In parallel
    • Developers
    • Non-Developers
    • And now ... also, AI and the Machines
  • Internal vs External
    • Internal
      • Different AuthNZ patterns
      • Proprietary information / links
    • External
      • Polished and use-case focused
      • Focused reasons to adopt

(9) Errors: What new consumers will see most!

  • 2xx: Success
  • 4xx: Client did something wrong
  • 5xx: Server broke ... send a ticket!
  • 400/401/403/500 - are essential status codes
    • Documenting these will help uncover bugs, and improve API usability


Types of API Documentation Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

Why you need good API Documentation

Why you need good API Documentation Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(14) Why you need good API Documentation

  • Teach you customers, prospects, employees, partners, and LLMs (or AI agents) about using your products & APIs
  • Define, test, and secure product boundaries for the organization and/or consumers
  • Enable customer support, and promote self-service / self-help
  • Support technical marketing efforts
  • Improve API discoverability: are APIs findable and are their docs usable


Why you need good API Documentation Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(15) The internal benefits of good API Documentation

  • Avoid/reduce duplicated effort
  • Improved organizational understanding of products/platforms
  • Improved consistency, standardization, and security
    • Expose inconsistencies: compare docs across APIs (linted and validated)
    • Improve quality: implicit QA by doc writers, explicit functional view of testing
    • More secure: less room for errors in security and operations


Why you need good API Documentation Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(16) The external benefits of good API Documentation

  • Increase adoption by end consumers - better first impressions
  • Better relationships and sentiment with consumers
  • Improved reputation/credibility with the developer community
  • Improved stickiness giving ability to scale API footprint and ROI

(18) What makes a good API?



What makes a good API? Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(19) Tips: Generating Useful API References

Make sure your reference (e.g. OpenAPI Description) includes the following:

  • Explanation of what request data is required versus optional
  • The version of your API (via /v2 path or custom headers)
  • Authentication and other headers required for all requests (e.g. Token, JWT)
  • The resource path for each endpoint (e.g. /pets/{petId})
  • Which HTTP methods for each operation (e.g. GET, POST, PUT, PATCH)
  • The request fields and where each goes (e.g. query, path, body)
  • What to expect in each response
    • Example request and response data (response examples per status code)
    • Which HTTP status code are possible per endpoint/method combination
    • What each status code means in that context


What makes a good API? Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(20) Most Important API Documentation Features

  • Examples continue to be the best learning resource for consumers


What makes a good API? Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(21) Most Important API Documentation Features

  • Examples are twice as effective as code samples


What makes a good API? Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(22) Tips for Extensibility: Future-proofing APIs

  • Treat your API as a promise - don't break it!
  • Start with the smallest viable design and bake in extensibility practices from the beginning
Do
Define extension points
Define & communicate extensibility pattern (e.g. Must Ignore)
Apply versioning (when applicable)
Test for extensibility
Mock for extensibility tests
Communicate


What makes a good API? Frank Kilcommins: API Management in Practice: The Art of Good API Documentation

(23) Tips for Extensibility: Future-proofing APIs

  • Treat your API as a promise - don't break it!
  • Start with the smallest viable design and bake in extensibility practices from the beginning
Do Don't
Define extension points Don't add required inputs
Define & communicate extensibility pattern (e.g. Must Ignore) Don't remove outputs or make them optional
Apply versioning (when applicable) Don't change property types
Test for extensibility Don't add new properties which change the meaning of existing properties
Mock for extensibility tests Don't use too many booleans (only sparingly)
Communicate Don't be inconsistent in communication

(25) Exercise 2: Create an OpenAPI Description

  • Using the Example Mapping output for Retrieve Pet Details from exercise 1 to create an OpenAPI Description
  • Tooling of your choice:
    • https://editor-next.swagger.io
    • VS Code (or your IDE of choice)
    • ChatGPT or any other AI assistant
  • YAML or JSON!
